this video is brought to you by skill
share on paper Avatar The Last Airbender
looks like a pretty standard fantasy
story a journey magic powers a chosen
one and a bad guy bent on destroying him
and taking over the world now that's a
little oversimplified but those are all
pretty standard ingredients to a fantasy
story but what avatar does so right more
than so many fantasy novels and shows
through the years is the details
especially when it comes to the
characters it's a show that almost
always gave those characters both in the
main cast and in supporting roles more
nuance and depth than you might expect
from an action-adventure show on
Nickelodeon and I don't think that was
ever on display better than in what
might be my favorite episode of the
series tales of Ba Sing se from the
shows incredible second season an
episode told in a series of short
vignettes some fun and goofy and others
surprisingly moving everything I love
about the show is here so I wanted to
really dive into it this week and talk
about one of the crowning achievements
of animated TV and really TV in general
oh but before I do I should probably say
that YouTube's algorithm is really not a
fan of channels trying new things so if
you feel like throwing this video a like
or subscribe I definitely appreciate it
the episode begins with a story about
Katara and Toph though it's definitely
the earthbender who takes center stage
here the pair have a pretty low-key day
where Toph is convinced to go to the spa
and get her makeup and hair done only to
be mocked by a group of girls afterwards
the two dropped the group into a river
Katara makes Toph feel better and that's
basically it it's not the weightiest
story here admittedly but I do think it
sets the stage well especially
thematically for the episode one of the
things I like most about this episode is
how it makes some of these characters
confront how cutoff they are from what
most would consider a normal life the
opening of the story sees the rest of
the cast getting ready for their day in
the mirror and makes it clear that Toph
just doesn't care about that stuff she
wears her dirt and her lack of hygiene
with pride and for most of the season up
until
now it's really easy to take that at
face value like she just doesn't really
care about that stuff because she thinks
it's kind of dumb and pointless well not
really
what the rest of this short does so well
is illustrate how much of a defense
mechanism that is for Toph earthbending
is something she not only understands
but excels at throughout the show we see
how skilled and confident she is at it
but fashion makeup these are worlds that
are completely foreign to her and not
really by her choice either we see
earlier in the season how restrictive
tofs life was under her parents who hid
her away from the rest of the village to
the point where most didn't even know
she existed so of course the idea of a
day of the spa is a lot more terrifying
to her than any battle would be and
while her story isn't the highlight of
the episode I do think it serves as a
really important step for the character
and one that's kind of mirrored and Zuko
story I'm gonna kind of just throw out
what order they are in the actual
episode because I think this one just
makes sense to talk about here much like
it does for Toph if bossing say show
Zuko one thing it's how disconnected he
is from most people's everyday life
we're talking about a guy who was sat on
Fire Nation war councils launched
invasions and faced the wrath of the
Fire Lord himself and he's really scared
to go on a date in fact it's his uncle
who has to tell Zuko that the girl who
keeps coming into their tea shop
probably just likes him and isn't there
to do some Fire Nation espionage avatar
was always great with more subtle
character based humor and this Zuko
segment really packs it in I especially
like how annoyed Zuko is at his date
messing with his hair a little bit
because it took 10 whole minutes for his
uncle to style it their date goes about
as well as you'd expect with Zuko being
almost completely closed off and
secretive which really backs him into a
corner where he's forced to show off his
complete lack of juggling skills his
date Jen takes this all in stride though
and pretty soon she's leading him into
the town square for a romantic night
under the lanterns he lights them up and
they have a nice moment and
he just kind of shuts down and runs away
again this is a pretty low-key story but
one of the reasons I enjoy it so much
is that it forces Zuko into a situation
we're not used to seeing him in and
that's what so many fantasy and
adventure stories like avatar are
missing the show is interested in these
characters distinct personalities and
how they change and grow not just the
plot function that they serve in the
overall story arc it's a show that
doesn't have much interest in just
creating one-dimensional characters with
cool-looking powers it pretty rarely
settles for that an episodes like this
show why speaking of characters getting
pushed out of their comfort zones
we have Sokka this is probably the one
I'll spend the least amount of time on
other than maybe Aang's because it's
pretty lightweight and more of just a
comedy relief segment but I'm guessing
it taught a lot of kids what a hike who
was so that's something more seriously
though like Aang storyline it does give
us a peek into the city of Ba Sing se
and how it might not be quite as great
as it looks at first glance really
though my favorite part of this little
section is Sokka getting kicked out only
when he fails to nail a haiku many
syllables there bub so if this episode
is remembered for one thing it's the
uncle Iroh segment maybe it's because I
came to the show a little older than
most but honestly he's always been my
favorite character tragic funny and
almost always incredibly laid-back Iroh
is maybe the best example of how the
show isn't willing to settle for bland
predictable characterization here we
just follow him as he goes about his day
offering comfort and advice to a lot of
kids and even a young man who tries to
rob him along the way then he gets to a
tree outside the city and sets up a
small memorial for his son presumably at
the site where he died and sings a song
to him it's as simple as it is movie
like there's no real conflict in this
story even when he's threatened at
knifepoint he is not in much danger but
this isn't a story about conflict
it's a story about loss and to an extent
about the fire nation itself IRA offers
advice to almost everyone he talks to in
this episode whether it's the kids who
hit a ball into a window his would-be
mugger and even Zuko
but the final scene of the segment puts
all of that into a totally different
context all of those conversations
become reflections of what he lost of
advice that he wishes or maybe at one
point even did give to a son that he no
longer has he's always trying to get
Zuko to loosen up to live life a little
more and not just focus on impressing
his father and in season one that
usually just comes off as simple comic
relief but the more you learn about Iroh
the more his laid-back attitude in
season one feels like a quiet rebellion
all those invasions don't matter to him
much anymore he doesn't buy into the
glory of war or the idea of dying for
the Fire Nation he's seen exactly where
that leads
so his real loyalty is to his nephew
who's basically his surrogate son I also
just love the song that they wrote for
this episode leaves from the vine it's
only a few verses long but it manages to
feel surprisingly realistic it really
does feel like an ancient tune handed
down from generation to generation in
the fire nation that continues to
resonate as yet another wave of
idealistic young soldiers are sent off
to war the song feels like it's written
by an older person with a jaded attitude
towards war the soldiers aren't
described as powerful or even
particularly noble but as fragile tiny
shells drifting in the foam and all the
singer can help for is that they
eventually come marching home this sad
and resigned attitude just feels like
such a natural product of the fire
nation's constant Wars I think it's some
of the absolute best and most subtle
world building that this show ever did
the fact that a Nickelodeon show
balances this stuff so well with fun and
jokes is what makes this show so special
even all these years later
Aang and Momo stories represent the
other side of the show to varying
degrees
Angora causes a stampede trying to move
some animals
from their nasty zoo in the middle of
town into a new space almost plays like
a Warner Brothers Looney Tunes short
with an kind of as our Bugs Bunny
getting in way over his head but
ultimately coming out on top Momo story
though feels a little less Looney Tunes
and a little more pixar short with the
character trying in vain to find Appa so
many of the stories in this episode come
back to the same things characters
feeling out of place being pushed out of
their comfort zone or thinking about
what they've lost
now Momo's loss of Appa isn't tragic on
the scale of Iroh losing his son but man
does that final segment make you feel it
and while it isn't my favorite part of
the episode I think it's simple dialogue
list story sums up what tales of Ba Sing
se does so well it delivers so many
character moments large and small funny
and sad in just a few short minutes it's
far from the most ambitious episode of
the series or really even of season 2
but almost everything the show did well
is on display here and that's the reason
I'm still talking about this episode
years later avatar the last airbender
was always a show that excelled at
writing character moments and if you're
